title: Before 26 December 2020, will the Australian government accuse the Chinese government, by name, of being behind the "copy-paste compromises" cyberattacks?
preds: I guess $ count more than truth. While still a fan of Ozzies in general, they aren’t the Ozzies I knew in past. I miss one of my footy lads screaming “Ozzie Ozzie Ozzie oi oi oi!”...
Strategy appears to be not to name names as the situation is inflamed enough as it is.
It seems unlikely considering they knew it was a "state-based" actor since June and did not say which state yet. With such a short time frame, I have to go with less than 1% chance this will happen.
Less and less likely by the day.

Time is running out for this to occur.  On the other side, rhetoric has heated up lately between the two countries.  Therefore happy to say there's a non-zero chance of this occurring, but the time left is minimal

Unnamed officials have blamed China, but so far nothing specific from the PM or cabinet ministers. It's still possible Australia will call out China before December 26, but it seems like if it was going to happen it would have happened by now. Seems unlikely.

Winnie the Pooh just doesn’t have a sense of humour...
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-03/china-to-halt-key-australian-commodity-imports-as-tensions-mount

tensions have eased, and not much time left until the end date.  However these things can happen quickly and unexpectedly (ie. by definition cyber attacks happen quickly and unexpectedly).  So still a small outside chance of an attack happening and Australia therefore accusing China accordingly.

https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-04/cyber-attacks-on-australia-peace-war-defence-minister/12626396
Federal government officials have indicated that China is behind cyber attacks against Australia, which is not the PM or his Ministers and avoiding any diplomatic incidents,  one assumes.

Minister for HA Peter Dutton has given Australia a heightened warning in regards to cyber attacks on critical infrastructure.
https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/consequences-catastrophic-dutton-says-cyber-attacks-on-critical-infrastructure-rising-20201021-p56732.html

Winnie The Pooh does not take kindly to even potential insults.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-12/australia-dials-up-beijing-seeking-clarity-on-coal-import-ban
if found it will be covered up
Down to 0%. Aussie politician (as opposed to general population) cowards!

Australia has to run a narrow diplomatic line between upsetting its largest trading partner (who else will buy its commodity produce) who provide 49% of total exports and issues concerning a troubling foreign interference into its political structures.
Relations are low at he moment given tit-for-tat detaining of journalists based in each other’s countries and China’s face-saving reaction to Australia’s request for a study into the origin of Covid-19.
A Dirk van der Kley form the China Matters* think tank based in Canberra has advocated the hiring of a ‘Foreign Interference Commissioner” to be based at the Australian Human Rights Commission.
Given the title of the think tank, there is only one foreign country they are thinking about, but the Human rights angle seems odd. Such a position/department would possibly monitor the situation without handing out accuations.
Cyber attacks can be used anonymously or to send a message without the collateral damage, but not necessary to raise the diplomatic temperature.
My proposal is that accusations will have little value at this time and have reduced the likelihood accordingly. * China Matters is an Australian policy institute whose aim is to stimulate thinking amongst Australian business, Government and security concerning the PRC and develop policy. https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-03/china-australia-deteriorating-trade-diplomatic-relationship/12618738  https://www.france24.com/en/20200908-could-souring-china-australia-relations-force-a-rethink-on-trade  https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/09/11/australia-defends-raid-chinese-journalists/  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-17/australia-needs-foreign-interference-commissioner-china-tensions/12670516  http://chinamatters.org.au

There have been growing tensions between China and Australia during the COVID pandemic, particularly around a formal investigation of the source. Additionally, Australian journalists are being held in China for reasons not released to the public. The TikTok app has also been topical and related to China. This tension could contribute to the Australian government mentioning China as the source however, there may be more of a restriction to specifically name the Chinese government. 
Lifting the likelihood of any reports directly naming the China government was the recent change to Australia’s extradition treaty with Hong Kong in response to fears over a new national security law imposed by China. The Chinese Government urged the Australian government to immediately stop involving themselves in these issues, with a threatening style quote deriving from the Chinese Embassy: “…otherwise it will lead to nothing but lifting a rock only to hit its own feet".  
Because of the length of time since PM Morrison reported this to media (June 2020) and the growing tensions between China and Australia, there is an increased chance someone in the Australian Government will identify the Chinese Government as responsible for the attack. 
In contrast, the clandestine nature in which ASD operate, and the number of escalating factors involved, there may be an increased level of caution in identifying the Chinese Government for fears of an ongoing feud and retribution (so the probability must be below 50%), however if there is significant evidence, Australia is unlikely to hold back. 
It is likely Australia will only use estimative language in any accusations against the Chinese Government. In this sense of the question, they will not directly accuse China (and provide 0% chance) but there have been examples in the past where Australia has stated: “China is likely behind the sustained cyber attack” and “One expert says there has been increased espionage activity looking to extract material related to COVID-19”. This increases the probability of this scenario occurring.
It's not happening is it?! Plenty of time and tantrums.

Has become a non-issue over the last month or so. Federal government is unlikely to want to goad China given the trade bans China has implemented recently. https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-08-19/china-eyes-australian-wine-export-in-latest-trade-move/12571672

Want to illuminate a concept. This is a "carry trade", something used by currency traders when they invest in a currency returning a higher interest rate. It's a low short term risk but high long term risk trade.  I think of many bets here as carry trades. When you bet with the crowd but slightly higher than the crowd, that's a carry trade.  In a tournament, it's wise to make plenty of carry trades. If you're playing for the long run, carry trades will likely result in a frustrating reversion to the mean.
I feel like they would've done so by now...
Australia not looking likely to do this right now, and as the time passes, it is getting to the point of what use it would serve to do this?!  Lowered for now.

There is a tit for tat, but this is unlikely.  We need China's money and about the only thing our PM does exceptionally is to learn for his mistakes, we directly called China out (rather than using softerlanguage) on dragging their feet on an investigation into covid-19 and it hurt the country economically. We're unlikely to do it again.

Seems like there is further verbal escalation, raising for the possibility that Australia respond in the near future. Source: https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8590263/amp/Unbearable-consequences-China-issues-barbed-warning-Australia.html

Out of the 24 countries who have been victims of cyber warfare on the Wikipedia page for Chinese intelligence activity abroad, only 2 of them (the US and Belgium) have actually called out China directly by name. (1) That gives a base rate of 8%. I have assumed that the outcome that Australian politicians will be considering for calling out china is trade sanctions. I have therefore adjusted my probability down to around 2% due to Australia's dependency on China for exporting.  I then added around 2% for the possibility of a minister accidentally naming China. This is based on the fact that in the 24 cases mentioned none of them accidentally named China, though Canada (1/24 = 4.17%) almost did. Therefore we get approx 2+2 = 4% There should be some scaling downwards of the probability for the amount of time left in the question, not sure how to go about doing this. It would make sense for countries to call out China closer to the cyber attacks in question, but the short time frame of the question could mean this effect is negligible. The fact that they haven't named China yet would suggest that they are less likely to, compared to the base rate which includes Belgium seemingly naming them very soon after major cyber attacks (2) Therefore adjusted somewhat arbitrarily down to 3% to reflect this. Any criticism/comments are welcome, I am new to this. (1) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_intelligence_activity_abroad
(2) https://www.sophos.com/en-us/press-office/press-releases/2008/05/belgium.aspx

Lowering confidence due to the below article which in its essence was: <source> At the same time, she said Australia did not agree on everything with Beijing - or with the United States. “The relationship that we have with China is important. And we have no intention of injuring it,” she said. “But nor do we intend to do things that are contrary to our interests.” She said Australia and the United States had a shared interest in an Asia-Pacific region that was free, prosperous and secure and were broadly aligned on issues, including China. </source> She being the Australian Foreign Minister, Marise Payne. Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-australia-pompeo/australia-tells-us-it-has-no-intention-of-injuring-important-china-ties-idUSKCN24T2MP

China is a huge trading partner to Australia and I don’t expect Australian government to jeopardize this further by making direct accusation to China. Unless forced by their Western allies (US primarily). I give 20% at this point, considering that Australians would leave the tension to ease, rather than adding fuel to the fire.

Source 1 shows us that Australia has begun their vocalisation of China actions, in this instance regarding the South China Sea claim. Unless Aus cannot prove or have a high-degree of probability that China performed these attacks, I cannot at present understand why Aus wouldn't follow up with this call out too in the time allocated. If nothing by Oct/Nov my confidence will fall dramatically. With regards to Source 2, it seems that the call-out is more likely especially in regards to: - Hackers linked to China allegedly stole more than 300 gigabytes of data from an Australian defence contractor including technical information, according to an indictment unsealed by the US justice department. The Australian government said on Wednesday it was concerned by the alleged intrusions and welcomed “actions designed to hold malicious cyber actors to account” after the US announced a raft of charges against two Chinese nationals. But the opposition argued the government was not doing enough to safeguard critical infrastructure and businesses from cyber threats. However, taking into account the below: - Relations between Australia and China have come under repeated strain this year, but tensions boiled over last month when Beijing accused Canberra of engaging in a campaign of “cyber espionage, spying and surveillance on foreign governments, companies and individuals”. This week, an industry panel advising the Australian government on cybersecurity urged it to adopt a more “forward-leaning posture” on naming the countries behind cyber-attacks – including working with close partners to jointly attribute responsibility. The Australian government declared last week its support for a joint cybersecurity advisory issued by the US, UK and China “which details malicious cyber activity by Russian actors targeting organisations involved in Covid-19 vaccine development”. In that case, however, Australia named Russia – calling on it “to cease immediately any cyber activity, or support for such activity, which is inconsistent with their international commitments”. It is possible that China was not the perpetrator at all (albeit unlikely), and more Russia either independently, on behalf of/in cahoots with China. Source 1: https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/australia-rejects-beijing-south-china-sea-claims-200724223250039.html
Source 2: https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/jul/22/hackers-linked-to-china-allegedly-stole-data-from-australian-defence-contractor

UK is releasing their Russia report now.  UK has actively asked other countries (which I definitely think includes Aus) to speak up about their issues - China has been named regarding HK by UK recently, also interesting is the glowing praise for US for doing so; seems to me that there is going to be some calling out internationally or who could take that nation seriously in the future?! Brave New World. Therefore, increasing my % for the next few weeks to see if there is a domino fall of condemnation against China and Russia. Everyone is pointing their spears (slowly) towards their obvious enemies.

With the UK and US going in on China and calling them out. Aus must feel compelled to stand up for their position in the coming weeks.  The time frame  available gives me the confidence on this starting position, of course as time passes the odds will decrease accordingly.

The media are declaring that China is responsible for the cyber-attacks on Australian systems.
The Australian government has stated that the attacks were carried out by state actors such as Russia, Iran, North Korea and China.
Morrison has essentially issued a warning that the State is known and want it stopped.
China appears to be beyond embarrassment with its growing superpower status.
Whether or not the Australian Government name China as the source of the cyber-attack depends on the level of tension between Australia and China and the pressure by the international community concerning Covid-19, Hong Kong, Spratly Islands, Indian border etc.
It is conceivable that given the vocal potential of Australian Senators that China could be named in Parliament that force the Government into clarifying their position.
The Australian Government has joined others in naming Russia in hacking Covid-19 researchers in the west. Therefore, with backing from its allies, Australia could name China directly.
I propose a 40% chance of the  Australian Government naming China directly by 26 December 2020. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8531559/Iranian-spies-accidentally-leaked-videos-hacking-showing-stealing-email-accounts.html  https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8532793/Putin-certainly-knew-Covid-hacking-says-former-intelligence-chair.html  https://www.wired.com/story/china-hackers-covid-19-spying-vaccine/  https://www.livemint.com/technology/tech-news/chinese-hackers-suspected-behind-massive-cyber-attack-in-australia-11592545383344.html  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-06-20/why-australia-acted-on-china-hacking-cyber-attack-scott-morrison/12376700  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-46096768  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-06-20/aspi-denies-sole-org-blaming-china-for-hacking/12376478  https://www.zdnet.com/article/prime-minister-says-australia-is-under-cyber-attack-from-state-based-actor/  https://www.theage.com.au/world/europe/russia-accused-of-trying-to-steal-virus-vaccine-secrets-20200717-p55cva.html
There are other possible countries behind this Attack, example north Korea. Australia is very cautious about international issues for that reason I think they could not accuse China.
Better left unsaid. The moment is gone and there are lots of other things to say.
Lowering for passage of time. Australia mentioned state actor but not who. Put out specific information on to combat copy paste attack.
https://time.com/5864608/australia-hong-kong-extradition-treaty-suspended/ Australia continues to find ways to strike at China without having to name them outright for the hacking.

Australia could simply name China in the media, or be more effective and utilize the Copy-Paste attacks as a platform to draw talent out of China/Hong Kong. The recent Visa declaration aimed at immigrating high talent HK’s and directly benefit the Aussie nation economically pains China.

Pure economics, Australia cannot rely on the US, England the EU are courting money from China, so eventually Australia will have to tone down keep the facts to a behind the scenes negotiation and publicly keep it quiet.
For the Australian economy is all about selling in China, so staying quiet in public and allow the Chinese save face, it is the path on a technical spat.

Australia could simply name China in the media, or be more effective and utilize the Copy-Paste attacks as a platform to draw talent out of China/Hong Kong. The recent Visa declaration aimed at immigrating high talent HK’s and directly benefit the Aussie nation economically pains China.

Decreasing from 10 to 5. It's now fair to say other events (Hong Kong visa, student warnings) have filled the news cycle and this issue is a memory. The chances of a minister accidentally naming China with relation to this specific attack is now very very low.
Australia is escalating on tensions further: https://time.com/5864608/australia-hong-kong-extradition-treaty-suspended/

News that Australia took part in South China Sea training exercises with the US which seems to make the case they are still doing things to push back on China without outwardly naming them.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-shows-off-its-firepower-to-beijing-in-south-china-sea-11593965632?st=s5bwowxaisb7wgk&reflink=article_copyURL_share

I can find no mention in online reports of an official investigation and report to be published. Yet another indication that the Chinese will not be accused by name. Morrison has made it clear who he thinks it is but with so much trade at stake has to tread lightly. As others have already pointed out, you can never rule out a cabinet minister blurting it out so unless unforeseen events occur a low probability remains.

Seems unlikely given that the Federal government has refused to name China to date. There is no inquiry into the attacks which seems most the likely platform to name China. Always the danger of a rogue cabinet minister blurting it out though.

I can only see this being done in the context of a further worsening of the relationship - potentially over Hong Kong, as the world already knows who Australia meant. For now hard to see the motivation from Australia in escalating

Offiical institutions have already declared the acts to be state-sponsored. Some indirect reports from ACSC and others tend to suggest that similar patterns from Chinese threat actors were previously identified and reported. However, while limited publicly available information make it hard to say with certainty that China is that state sponsor, the reluctance of the Australian govt. to name China may be the strongest indicator that it could be China. There has been a pattern of hostile behaviour between both countries. Australian officials may be waiting to a) get solid evidence, or b) may be anticipating adverse consequences or c) may not be in what they view to be the right position to face the backlash following the statement. As such, the odds that Australia accuses China are probably hoovering at between 25 and 55%. 50% seems to be a fair compromise today.
Enough number of supporters of Chinese government within the rich and powerful in Australia to pressure the Australian government to not do this.

Unlikely for them to call out on their own when they have better ways to call out China without such tradeoff.. Unless information is released which is widely and publicly available between now-Nov - most possibly by legit and non-state sources - then I will increase my probability to 14%. Possible for opposition to do so, more than the govt.
Value of directly naming unclear and would increase potential of further actions in cyber or other domain (e.g. trade).

7/2/2020
- Morrison and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi signed a military pact allowing each country to utilize the other's military bases (further military escalation; greater chance an enemy is named) [8] 7/1/2020
- Morrison announces significant increase in military budget; does not say explicitly that the reason is China, but it is assumed that it is (increased tensions; increased chance that ministers actually name an enemy) [7] 6/30/2020 - Strong history of the PM and his cabinet not naming China, but instead referring to the culprit as a "state-actor" [1][2] 
- Peter Jennings, Executive Director of the ASPI, has named China outright, but he is not apart of the cabinet-level, though presumably he reports to the Minister of Defense [3] 
- Seems to be general fear over damaging relationships with China [4] 
- General conclusion by the media, based on statements from unnamed government officials point to China, indicating that the government likely knows that it is them [5] 
- Scott Morrison has named foreign governments as the culprits of cyber attacks in the past, namely he blamed Russia for meddling in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election (much different than blaming China, however, as they don't have significant economic ties with the country) [6] [1] https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2019/feb/19/china-rejects-australian-parliament-cyber-attack-claims-as-baseless-and-irresponsible

2015 - Australia blaims China for spying, which China denies. 
2019 - More tension between Australia and China and more cyberattacks. PM also blaims a sophisicated state actor, which would strongly imply China. However, actually blaiming China will need a lot more attacks in my opinion, else he would have done it already.

Difficulty of substantiating attribution, especially to government actors
The tendency of states to name China for these actions is low. Impact on trade is high and the effect of China's influence on other states in the region will be detrimental to AUS and its economy.
They are investing tons of money in cybersecurity. They will find out a lot more about it.

There has been a lot of good analysis on this thread with many good links. Nothing I have from my brief learning is ground breaking. My few thoughts though to look back on: What would be in it for the Australian government to name China?
1. Look strong to the Australian public / world 
2. Try and rebuff further actions by China What are the negatives?
1. Provoke further attacks with China, especially given that China will want to defend strength to their people
2. Damage trade relations with China
3. Get into an international battle with China as China tries to defend itself from COVID scrutiny, activity in the South China Sea, India, etc. Seems like the negatives outweigh the positives significantly. Also, Peter Jennings named China outright (Australian strategic policy) which effectively names China if not formally. Australia already making their own moves by investing in cyber security which shows companies and they’re people that they’re taking action. The initial rush after the most recent act will have worn off. Starting at 15% and will wait for further developments.  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/30/world/australia/cyber-defense-china-hacking.html
Surely some cabinet minister will accidentally name them

It is incredibly unlikely that Australia will publicly name China as responsible for these cyber-attacks. This type of action would, most likely, bring additional Chinese pressure against Australia and Australia does not need to name China to let China know that Australia knows what China is doing [1]. Further, Australia has a history of not naming China when the country knows that China has conducted cyber attacks in the past [2]. Finally, The Australian government has publicly called for an investigation into the COVID-19 pandemic, which offended China[3]. Finally, as Australia is dependent on China for trade, and both countries are engaged in "cold" trade war[4], it is unlikely that the Australian government will take economic risks by publicly calling out China as the attacker of these cyber attacks. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/jun/20/scott-morrison-sends-china-a-signal-on-cyber-attack-but-then-fear-turns-into-farce
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-australia-china-cyber-exclusive/exclusive-australia-concluded-china-was-behind-hack-on-parliament-political-parties-sources-idUSKBN1W00VF
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-australia-china-cyber-exclusive/exclusive-australia-concluded-china-was-behind-hack-on-parliament-political-parties-sources-idUSKBN1W00VF
[4] https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/may/20/australian-wool-producers-particularly-exposed-if-trade-tensions-with-china-rise

They don't need to publicly. The coalition government will not risk further tantrums from China that have real (and headline grabbing) economic impacts by actually naming and shaming. 
I'm leaving the 10% potential there because David Speers might catch a minister off guard on a Sunday morning. ;)

China is the nemesis du jour. Too many stories of espionage, genocide, info cover up, etc. Not saying those items are founded in untruths but makes them a target nonetheless. Not to mention the unknown attraction to xenophobia that seems to be infecting the world.

As all suspect it is china already there is absolutely zero to be gained in pointing it out. Best to lie back and think of England to borrow a phrase. One does not want to upset the few remaining horses.

Australia has, in recent times shown, no qualms in opposing China on the international stage. Given that the evidence of the insofar anonymous state-actor being China is bound to grow to a point where the claim can be made with reasonable certainty in the scope of the next few months, Australia has no incentive to not bring this matter as lucidly as possible to get ensure other countries make a note of it

Let's begin to update! First, China seems to be launching her counterattack on Australia: according to the Global Times [1], Australia is intensifying her spionage over China. The news also _unironically_ shows a picture of the spy gear of someone caught in 2018, including funds, metro maps, a compass and gloves. It has also appeared on aussie media [2]. Besides that, apparently calling the cyber attacker by name is not necessarily an unseen tactic: the Germans have done it with the Russians [3]: "The German Ministry of Foreign Affairs informed Moscow on May 28...". From this I would not consider totally out of the question that Australia could decide to point the finger directly to China. Now @geo pointed out in a comment that a reason why Australia might not call it by name could be the prisoner's dilemma: as relationships with Canada and other countries are in a all time low, Australia might seek rapprochement to resume exports to China. This is a real possibility, as this has been an usual tactic by the Chinese diplomacy during the last twenty years or so. However it is also true that tensions are more serious than ever and that it can be considered that China is already at war with the West. For instance, if we read the book "Unrestricted warfare" [4] and review what China has been doing, then a really worrisome pattern emerges. From this point of view it would not be surprising that the most affected countries, in particular Australia which is a primary target of Chinese influence operations as they want to check whether they can break the lines of the Anglo-saxon countries, would began to be more aggressive towards China. Finally, there were rumors that the Chinese stopped many imports because they are short of foreign currency reserves (owing to less exports) but they still want to try to honor the phase one trade deal, because despite the rhetoric an intensification of the trade war with the US would be potentially negative at this moment. Thus they began by stopping a few non-essential AU imports and then after the new outbreak in Beijing they suggested that the virus came from imported food from Europe (these imports can now plunge without the need of a diplomatic brawl). However this is just a somewhat conspiranoid theory (except that with the Chinese government, conspiranoia is often a good analysis tool). [1] https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1192847.shtml
[2] https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-06-29/chinese-state-media-says-australia-is-stepping-up-spy-activities/12402032
[3] https://www.lawfareblog.com/case-against-eu-cyber-sanctions-bundestag-hack
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unrestricted_Warfare

The rationales below are the best part of this question.
I love the thought process/experiment of why/to what end and the reverse engineering of cat and mouse. I recall additional headlines about tensions and squabbles between China and Australia. The tone and tenor of Australia reminds me of a mix between Canada and Texas, with Australia calling out the one-way relationship between the two. 
Sure, Australia has little to gain from calling out China, but it isn't like it is going to hurt tourism, C-19 has already done that. Speaking of, I'm sure there are a lot of unemployed Australians that are plenty ticked off at this pandemic that has its roots in China. I think a government has more to gain from silently knowing what they know and not tipping their hand, but the citizenry expects their government to be an amplifier of their outrage. Let's not forget, China needs the business too. There is little to lose from pointing it out when you see something amiss.  That said, as time ticks on, this becomes less likely, and if this resolves "yes," it'll likely happen rather quietly.

Australia depends of China economically: Meet exports, Chinese tourists, commodities exports, ... ASEAN countries are tourist targets for many Australians. But China created hegemony about some by “Road and Belt” initiatives and may influence some to push back the number of Australian tourists. Australia may hit by NSA cyberattacks because they should assume wrongly that it might be hit by China cyberattacks. Both thoughts make it more likely, that Australia remains silent. The USA attacks by CIA and NSA under Sitting President highly aggressive allies and adversaries countries. The USA and not China disturbance the existing world order and is obviously the main aggressor from my point of view. Australia as ally of USA will not bear more burden by wrongly accusing China.
I ask what is to be gained by making an explicit reference for a petty crime. Talking about it gives Austraila far more room, once named the suspense is over.

I would like to narrate a short story here.  Mr A is a family man who stays in suburban America (keeping things relevant for the majority, but this story could play out anywhere in the world).  Mr A has a next door neighbor Mr C (who drinks too much beer and reads too much Soldier of Fortune). Now Mr C might not be a good neighbor and Mr A might not like him, but their properties share a boundary. So Mr A restricts himself to the occasional complaining within his family. Recently things have gotten a bit heated, leading to a couple of shouting matches between Mr A and Mr C. And last night, Mr C's 10 year old brat had tried to TP Mr A's house in the dead of night. He did a pretty terrible job too, which confirmed Mr A's long held suspicion that the kid was not terribly bright! Now does Mr A:
1) Go to the cops and accuse the kid of TPing his house
2) Go out and buy a dog
3) Hire the best Pennywise costume possible and scare the bejeezus out of the brat  The Australian government is in the same predicament as Mr A above. They have a large dependence on China (for trade), but the Chinese have been belligerent and there is a measure of anti-China sentiment in Australia (which Scott Morrison would like to reap in 2022). He might also attribute his recent personal polling performance to his governments stance against China.  But these "copy paste compromises" seem a bit like a TP attack. Australia will have to accuse a state with significant resources of staging a sophisticated attack using unsophisticated "copy paste" attacks. Its just does not make sense!  Baseline estimates at 15% for yes. NOTE - There could very well be Chinese strings behind the "copy paste" puppets - but Australia would be better served by waiting. Or they could go out and get a dog.

Second update, in which I will go overboard for the sake of enjoying the moment. Of course I do not think that there is a 95% chance of this happening, but rather something around the 10% level. But it does not hurt to much to go crazy at the beginning of a question. Since the pandemic began, the relationship between Australia and China has plunged into an incredible show from which anything could be expected, at least in what regards bickering. A few points: (1) The Australian gov wanted an investigation on the covid-19 origins [1,2], which of course is anathema to China.
(2) Australia also wanted to have Taiwan in WHO [3], second no-go for China.
(3) The "totally independent" Chinese media outlet the Global Times called Australia "gum stuck to China's shoe" [4]
(4) China warned its citizens not to go to Australia, because racial violence [5]
(5) China threatens economic boycott to Australia [6]
(6) China suggests Australia to distance itself from the US [7] (we own you!)
(7) Australia and India sign a deal to use each other military bases [8]
(8) China's ban on Aussie beef and punitive tariffs on barley [9,10,11] This indicates that the Australia-China relationship has just become delightfully confrontational. Yet some of the movements by China are counterproductive to China's own interest, particularly the ones related to barley and beef. Now that the Chinese have suggested that the new outbreak in Beijing could be because of imports from Europe, they might need to be consistent with their own lies and reconsider imports from Australia. Or they might not, it's hard to tell. Yet there are a few factors that have not unfold yet: (a) the increase in confrontation between China and the US, which will lead to more tensions between Australia and China, (b) reactions to whatever happens in Hong-Kong, (c) whether China continues its current "Wolf warrior diplomacy" policy, which seems to be tailored to unite every western country (and many non-western ones) against China. However these increases in tension do not necessarily go on the direction of increasing the probability of some cabinet-level minister in Australia pointing out China by name. It could likely go into the other direction: not pointing out directly China as a way to reduce tensions on the thing that China values most: face.
